sentence_results.ground_truth_sentence:
Facts of the case

In 2010, for the first time in over forty years, Wisconsin voters elected a Republican majority in the state assembly and the senate, and a Republican governor.
sentence_results.best_match:
Facts of the Case
Wisconsin elects members of its State Legislature from single-member districts, with the legislature required by the Wisconsin Constitution to redraw district boundaries following each census.

sentence_results.ground_truth_sentence: As a result, the Republican leadership developed a voting district map that its drafters calculated would allow Republicans to maintain a majority under any likely voting scenario.

sentence_results.best_match: After the 2010 census, a Republican-controlled legislature passed, and a Republican governor signed, a new districting plan known as Act 43 (Wis. Stat.

Even before it was enacted, the plan faced two legal challenges, on constitutional and statutory grounds.
sentence_results.best_match:
Legal Question(s)
The Court addressed whether the plaintiffs demonstrated Article III standing to challenge the statewide constitutionality of Act 43, specifically whether they showed a particularized "injury in fact"—an invasion of a legally protected interest that is concrete and particularized, affecting them in a personal and individual way (Lujan v. Defenders of Wildlife, 504 U.S. 555, 560, and n. 1 (1992))—arising from alleged vote dilution via partisan gerrymandering.

sentence_results.ground_truth_sentence: A federal court upheld the plan as not violating the "one person one vote" principle nor violating the Equal Protection Clause.
sentence_results.best_match: The Court set no binding precedent on justiciability or merits of partisan gerrymandering but reaffirmed that standing requires proof of concrete, particularized, district-specific injury for vote dilution claims (distinguishing Gaffney v. Cummings, 412 U.S. 735 (1973); Davis v. Bandemer, 478 U.S. 109 (1986); Vieth v. Jubelirer, 541 U.S. 267 (2004); League of United Latin American Citizens v. Perry, 548 U.S. 399 (2006)); remedies must be tailored to proven injury; and left open other theories (e.g., associational harm).

Conclusion
The plaintiffs failed to demonstrate Article III standing, so there is no need to resolve any of the questions presented.
